choices.text: He may negotiate and bargain with God in return for a cure
He may exhibit clinical signs of depression in anticipation of the loss of life that will eventually occur
He may experience guilt over unresolved issues with loved ones
He may accept his death as inevitable and exhibit euthymic mood

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient, recently diagnosed with terminal cancer and given a poor prognosis by his physician, was initially in complete denial about his illness and the fact that he was going to die. Gradually, he became frustrated and angry at his fate and frequently asked, "Why me of all people?" According to Kübler-Ross, which of the following would most likely be the next stage in facing his death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to Kübler-Ross, the patient has progressed from denial to anger ("Why me?"). The next stage is typically bargaining, where patients may negotiate with a higher power for a cure or more time.

Elisabeth Kübler-Ross, a psychiatrist and thanatologist, proposed a framework to understand the emotional responses of patients facing terminal illness or death. While every individual experiences these emotions differently and not necessarily in a fixed order, the model outlines five commonly observed stages of coping with dying:

Explanation of Other Options:

He may exhibit clinical signs of depression in anticipation of the loss of life that will eventually occur (Option B): Depression - This is the fourth stage, which follows bargaining. It includes deeper emotional symptoms and potential clinical features like withdrawal, hopelessness, or suicidal ideation.

He may experience guilt over unresolved issues with loved ones (Option C): While guilt may arise during grief, it is not a formal stage in the Kübler-Ross model.

He may accept his death as inevitable and exhibit euthymic mood (Option D): This is the final stage, where the patient comes to peace with the inevitable. It cannot occur before bargaining and depression in this framework.

questions.text: A year after her husband died due to myocardial infarction, the wife again started exhibiting symptoms like feeling depressed, guilty, lonely and was not able to sleep. She developed these symptoms exactly on the same day that her husband died a year ago. This is termed as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An anniversary reaction refers to the rekindling of acute grief triggered by a special occasion, such as a holiday, birthday, or, most commonly, the anniversary of a loved one's death.

  • These reactions often occur on the same date the person died, or when the bereaved reaches the same age the deceased was at the time of death.
  • Although they generally become milder and briefer over time, they may feel like a reliving of the original grief and last for hours or days.
  • In the case described, the onset of depressive symptoms exactly a year after her husband's death is classic for an anniversary reaction.

Explanation of other options:

Birthday Reaction (Option B): Not directly mentioned in the provided source. While birthdays may act as triggers in anniversary reactions, the term itself is not used separately. Hence, it is subsumed under anniversary reaction.

Traumatic Grief (Option C): Often used interchangeably with Prolonged Grief Disorder. Involves persistent, intense grief and emotional pain that disrupts daily life, often after a sudden or violent loss. In the case described, symptoms are episodic and date-linked, not chronic or functionally impairing year-round.

Chronic Grief (Option D): A complicated grief reaction that is persistent and often marked by bitterness and idealisation of the deceased. More likely when the relationship was extremely close or dependent, or when social support is lacking. The case presented does not describe ongoing bitterness or idealisation; rather, it is episodic, triggered by an anniversary.

questions.text: Even 2 years after her son's death, a 56-year-old woman has intense sorrow, guilt, avoidance of reminders, and suicidal thoughts. All of the following describe her condition, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's persistent yearning, guilt, and avoidance two years after her son’s death indicate complicated grief, also termed pathological grief or Persistent Complex Bereavement Disorder (PCBD). These involve severe, prolonged grief impairing function.

Delayed grief refers to suppressed grief shortly after loss, not persistent symptoms years later.

Persistent Complex Bereavement Disorder (PCBD):

  • It is a form of complicated grief.
  • This condition is characterised by persistent, severe grief symptoms that last more than 12 months (in adults) and involve significant functional impairment or distress.

Based on DSM-5 criteria, the following symptoms have been seen since the death of someone close to them, disproportionate and inconsistent with sociocultural norms:

Group B symptoms:

  • Longing for the deceased
  • Sorry for/pain about the death
  • Preoccupation with the lost person
  • Preoccupation with the circumstances surrounding the death

Group C symptoms:

  • Difficulty accepting the death
  • Cannot believe or is numb to the loss
  • Difficulty thinking about positive memories
  • Bitter or angry about the loss
  • Self-blame
  • Avoidance of reminders
  • Inability to trust others
  • Feeling alone/ detached
  • Feeling empty or unable to function without the lost person
  • The desire to die to be with the deceased
  • Trouble finding a purpose independent of the deceased
  • Trouble/ reluctance in pursuing other interests

choices.text: 'Grief has a waxing and waning course' vs 'MDD has a persistent, pervasive pattern'
'Grief has mild and transient functional impairment' vs 'MDD has clinically significant distress or impairment'
'In grief, wish to die is with intent to unite with deceased' vs 'In MDD, death wishes / suicidal ideations are due to hopelessness and worthlessness'
'In Grief, self-esteem is not preserved' vs 'In MDD, self-esteem is usually preserved'

questions.text: To differentiate Grief vs Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), all of the following hold true, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The incorrect statement here is Option D, because:

  • In grief, self-esteem is typically preserved. The person may feel sad and miss the deceased, but does not feel worthless.
  • In contrast, MDD is often associated with low self-esteem, feelings of worthlessness, and excessive guilt that is not specifically tied to the loss.

Explanation of other options:

'Grief has a waxing and waning course' vs 'MDD has a persistent, pervasive pattern' (Option A): In grief, the sadness tends to come and go, often triggered by reminders (photos, anniversaries). In MDD, the low mood is persistent and not necessarily tied to external cues.

'Grief has mild and transient functional impairment' vs 'MDD has clinically significant distress or impairment' (Option B): People in grief can often still function in daily life (though with difficulty). In MDD, impairment in functioning (social, occupational, personal) is severe and clinically significant.

'In grief, wish to die is with intent to unite with deceased' vs 'In MDD, death wishes / suicidal ideations are due to hopelessness and worthlessness' (Option C): In grief, death wishes are sometimes fantasies about reunion, not active plans. In MDD, suicidal ideation is usually driven by despair, hopelessness, and low self-worth.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered natural grief therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mourning process is a natural psychological reaction to loss and is considered the most fundamental form of grief therapy.

  • It involves experiencing and expressing the full range of emotions related to the loss (such as sadness, anger, guilt), ultimately leading to emotional resolution and acceptance.
  • Normal grief does not typically require psychiatric intervention.
  • Attempts to suppress or avoid mourning (e.g., with medication or denial) can interfere with healthy adaptation.
  • Allowing oneself to go through the mourning process is essential for long-term psychological healing.

Explanation of other options:

Psychoanalysis (Option A): A deep, long-term therapy focusing on unconscious conflict; not appropriate or practical for normal grief.

Supportive Psychotherapy (Option B): Helpful in complicated grief or when the bereaved person seeks help, but not considered a "natural" therapy in the context of normal grief.

Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (Option D): CBT is an evidence-based therapy useful in treating complicated grief, depression, or anxiety, but it is a clinical intervention, not part of the natural mourning process.

choices.text: The lethal dose for ending life is given by a physician
The lethal dose for ending life is prescribed by a physician and taken by the patient on their own.
Withdrawing life support systems by the physician at the patient's request

questions.text: What is meant by Physician-Assisted suicide?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Physician-Assisted Suicide (PAS) refers to the act where a physician provides the means (typically a prescription for a lethal dose of medication) for a terminally ill, competent patient to end their own life. However, the act of taking the medication is performed by the patient themselves.
  • It is distinct from active euthanasia, in which a physician or another individual directly administers the means of death.
  • PAS maintains the patient's autonomy, they remain the actual agent of death.
  • It avoids the coercion concerns associated with euthanasia, though ethical debate remains.
  • PAS may involve:
    • Prescribing a lethal dose of medication
    • Providing a suicide device operated by the patient
    • Supplying means for the patient to inhale a lethal substance (e.g., carbon monoxide)

Explanation of Other Options:

The lethal dose for ending life is given by a physician (Option A): Describes active euthanasia, not PAS.

Withdrawing life support systems by the physician at the patient’s request (Option C): Describes passive euthanasia or withholding/withdrawing life-sustaining treatment, also distinct from PAS.

questions.text: Physician-assisted suicide and Euthanasia are legalised in all of the following countries, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Physician-Assisted Suicide (PAS) and euthanasia are legal in Netherlands, Belgium, and Canada under strict regulations (Options B, C, D). In India (Option A), active euthanasia and PAS are illegal, but passive euthanasia was legalized in 2018 under specific conditions.

  • In India, active euthanasia and PAS are illegal and considered criminal offences under the Indian Penal Code (IPC):
    • Section 302: Punishment for murder (if active euthanasia is performed).
    • Section 304: Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder (in some interpretations of euthanasia).
  • Only passive euthanasia (withholding/withdrawing life-sustaining treatment) has been legalised under specific conditions following the 2018 Supreme Court judgment, but this does not include physician-assisted suicide or active euthanasia.

Reference: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3701348/#__ffn_sectitle

questions.text: A 22-year-old medical student was searching the literature for depression and EEG. She was interested in knowing what changes would be seen in depression. What is the most likely EEG change seen in depression?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Depression significantly disrupts circadian rhythm and sleep architecture. EEG studies in depressed patients commonly show the following changes:

  • Decreased slow-wave sleep (deep NREM sleep): This is one of the most consistent findings and reflects impaired sleep quality. (Option D ruled out)
  • Reduced REM latency: The first REM period occurs earlier than usual after sleep onset.
  • Increased REM density and total REM sleep: REM episodes are more frequent and intense, especially early in the night. (Option A ruled out)
  • Increased nocturnal awakenings and reduced total sleep time
  • Increased core body temperature
  • Blunted growth hormone (GH) secretion, which normally occurs during slow-wave sleep.

Explanation of other options:

Increased delta waves (Option C): Incorrect. Delta waves (slow waves) are reduced, not increased.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common comorbidity associated with a panic disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Panic disorder is characterised by acute, intense attacks of anxiety accompanied by feelings of impending doom. These panic attacks can occur sporadically, from several in one day to just a few per year.
  • One of the most common comorbid conditions associated with panic disorder is agoraphobia, which is defined as:
    • "A fear of or anxiety regarding places from which escape might be difficult."
  • While panic attacks themselves are symptoms that can occur in multiple disorders, in panic disorder, agoraphobia often develops as a complication or comorbidity when patients begin to avoid situations where a panic attack might occur.

Explanation of other options:

Alcohol Use (Option B): Some patients use alcohol to self-medicate anxiety, but it is not the most frequent comorbidity.

Depression (Option C): Common in panic disorder, but usually occurs later due to chronic distress.

Social Anxiety Disorder (Option D): Less common. Involves fear of social situations, not sudden panic attacks.

choices.text: Cannabis use can precipitate psychosis in people who are vulnerable because of a family history of the disorder
Chronic cannabis use does not affect motivation and social performance
Long-term cannabis use causes physical dependence
Long-term cannabis use causes severe cognitive impairment

questions.text: A 21-year-old man informed you that he was a heavy user of cannabis. He was seeking advice about the risks associated with cannabis use. What would you tell him?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cannabis is the most widely used illicit drug, and its association with psychiatric effects is well documented. Cannabis use can precipitate psychotic symptoms, particularly in individuals with a family history or genetic predisposition to such illnesses.

  • The risk of developing psychosis is significantly higher in cannabis users, and this risk increases with early use, heavy use, and potency of the cannabis preparation.
  • Cannabis-induced psychotic disorder includes delusions, hallucinations, and disorganised thinking, which may resolve with abstinence but may persist in vulnerable individuals.
  • The psychotic episodes are sometimes called "hemp insanity."

Explanation of Other Options:

Chronic cannabis use does not affect motivation and social performance (Option B): Incorrect. Chronic cannabis use can impair motivation and social performance. This is known as amotivational syndrome, where users may become apathetic, less goal-directed, and socially withdrawn.

Long-term cannabis use causes physical dependence (Option C): Incorrect. Cannabis use does not typically lead to physical dependence, but psychological dependence can occur. Withdrawal symptoms like irritability, anxiety, and sleep disturbances may be seen, but these are generally mild.

Long-term cannabis use causes severe cognitive impairment (Option D): Incorrect. While some cognitive impairment (like attention and short-term memory issues) may be seen with chronic heavy use, severe cognitive impairment is not consistently observed and tends to improve after cessation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with agoraphobia was assessed for behaviour therapy. Which of the following is she fearful of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Agoraphobia is characterised by intense fear or anxiety of situations where escape may be difficult or help unavailable in the event of developing panic-like symptoms or other incapacitating symptoms.

  • Typical triggers include:
    • Crowds
    • Public transportation
    • Enclosed spaces (e.g., stores, elevators)
    • Open spaces (e.g., parks, bridges)
    • Being outside alone
  • Patients often avoid these situations or only face them with a companion.
  • In severe cases, they may be homebound.
  • While agoraphobia may occur with panic disorder, it is recognised in DSM-5 as a distinct diagnosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Family history (Option A): Incorrect. While relevant as a risk factor, it is not the object of fear in agoraphobia.

Heights (Option C): Incorrect. This represents acrophobia, a specific phobia, not agoraphobia.

Recent life events (Option D): Incorrect. Stressful events can trigger or exacerbate anxiety, but are not directly feared in agoraphobia.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is associated with negative symptoms of schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The negative symptoms of schizophrenia such as blunted affect, avolition, alogia, and anhedonia, are linked to dysfunction in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC).
  • According to neurocircuit-based models, dysfunction in the dorsolateral prefrontal circuit contributes to primary and enduring negative symptoms.
  • Imaging studies support this, showing reduced metabolic activity in this region, especially when patients exhibit prominent negative symptoms.
  • This dysfunction may result from early developmental lesions in dopaminergic tracts, affecting both prefrontal and limbic systems.

Explanation of other options:

Hippocampus (Option B): Incorrect. While hippocampal abnormalities are seen in schizophrenia and relate to memory dysfunction and altered limbic-prefrontal interactions, they are not primarily associated with negative symptoms. Instead, they are involved in working memory and possibly auditory hallucinations via prefrontal-limbic circuits.

Lateral ventricles (Option C): Incorrect. Enlargement of lateral ventricles is a common but non-specific finding in schizophrenia. It reflects global brain atrophy, but does not directly correlate with either positive or negative symptom severity.

Mesolimbic tract (Option D): Incorrect. The mesolimbic dopaminergic pathway is hyperactive in schizophrenia and is primarily associated with positive symptoms like hallucinations and delusions, not with negative symptoms.

questions.text: Which is the last stage of psychosocial development as described by Erikson?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Erik Erikson proposed eight stages of psychosocial development that extend from infancy to old age. Each stage presents a unique conflict that serves as a turning point in development.

The eighth and final stage is: Integrity vs. Despair (Late Adulthood, ~65 years and older):

  • In this stage, individuals reflect on their lives.
  • If they feel fulfilled and that their life has meaning, they achieve a sense of integrity.
  • If they feel regret, guilt, or dissatisfaction, they may fall into despair, fearing death and feeling that life was wasted.
  • This stage determines whether the individual develops wisdom and acceptance, or bitterness and fear of death.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy experimented with 'eating by himself with confidence'. What stage of Erikson's psychosocial development is represented in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At 4 years old, a child is in the "Initiative vs. Guilt" stage of Erikson's psychosocial development, which occurs roughly between 3 to 5 years of age.

  • In this stage, children begin to assert control and power over their environment by initiating activities, making decisions, and trying new things, like feeding themselves, dressing, or asking questions.
  • Success in this stage leads to a sense of purpose and confidence.
  • If discouraged or punished harshly, children may develop guilt and become reluctant to take initiative.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man died because of a cardiac arrest in the intensive care unit. The treating doctor believed that he was responsible for the patient's death despite knowing that the patient had a poor prognosis. Which is the most likely cognitive distortion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Personalisation is a cognitive distortion where someone blames themselves for external events, even when they are not responsible.
  • In this case, the doctor assumes personal responsibility for the patient's death, despite knowing that the patient had a poor prognosis.
  • This self-blame, without a factual basis, is a classic example of personalisation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male trainee accountant passed the first 2 years of examinations but failed the last year. Since failing, he had started to think that he was 'good for nothing'. Which is the most likely cognitive bias?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Overgeneralization involves drawing broad, sweeping conclusions based on a single event or limited evidence.
  • In this case, the man failed one exam and then concluded that he was "good for nothing," ignoring his earlier success.
  • He applies one negative outcome to his entire self-worth, a hallmark of overgeneralization.

Explanation of other options:

Arbitrary inference (Option A): Making a negative conclusion without sufficient evidence. E.g., "He didn't smile at me, so he must hate me." Here, the man does have a negative event (exam failure), so this is not arbitrary.

Catastrophic thinking(Option B): Expecting or imagining the worst possible outcome. E.g., "If I fail, I'll never get a job and my life will be ruined." In this case, he's making a global judgment about himself, not forecasting doom.

Dichotomous thinking (Option C) (Black-and-white thinking): Seeing things in all-or-nothing terms. E.g., "Either I pass everything or I'm a total failure." This isn't primarily a black-and-white evaluation, but an overgeneralization from one event to his whole identity.

choices.text: Aversive conditioning pairs an unpleasant stimulus with a behaviour to reduce its frequency
Classic conditioning is the association of a neutral stimulus with a conditioned stimulus, which brings the response originally elicited by an unconditioned stimulus
In habituation, the response to a repeated stimulus increases over time
In operant conditioning, behaviour frequency is altered by observational learning

questions.text: Which of the following statements about learning theory is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In classical conditioning (pioneered by Ivan Pavlov), a neutral stimulus (like a bell) is repeatedly paired with an unconditioned stimulus (like food) that naturally produces a response (like salivation). Over time, the neutral stimulus becomes a conditioned stimulus, and it alone can produce the response, now called a conditioned response.

For example:

  • Bell (neutral stimulus) + Food (unconditioned stimulus) → Salivation (unconditioned response)
  • After several pairings: Bell alone → Salivation (conditioned response)

Explanation of other options:

Aversive conditioning pairs an unpleasant stimulus with a behaviour to reduce its frequency (Option A): Incorrect because aversive conditioning involves pairing an unpleasant stimulus with an unwanted behaviour to create a negative association, not simply punishment. Punishment in operant conditioning can reduce behaviour, but aversive conditioning is a classical conditioning technique.

In habituation, the response to a repeated stimulus increases over time (Option C): Incorrect. In habituation, the response to a repeated, non-threatening stimulus decreases over time (e.g., getting used to a ticking clock).

In operant conditioning, behaviour frequency is altered by observational learning (Option D): Incorrect. In operant conditioning, behaviour is altered by reinforcement or punishment, not by observing others. Observational learning is a part of social learning theory (Albert Bandura), not operant conditioning.

choices.text: Classical conditioning is driven by an individual's actions
Learning is defined as a change in cognitive functioning
Operant learning is a result of environmental events
Social learning incorporates both classic and operant models

questions.text: Which of the following statements about learning is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Social learning theory, proposed by Albert Bandura, integrates elements from both classical and operant conditioning. It emphasises that learning can occur through observation, imitation, and modelling, even without direct reinforcement. For example, a person can learn behaviours by watching others being rewarded or punished.

Thus, social learning combines:

  • Classical conditioning (associative learning),
  • Operant conditioning (learning through consequences),
  • And cognitive processes like attention and memory.

Explanation of other options:

Classical conditioning is driven by an individual's actions (Option A): Incorrect. Classical conditioning is not based on a person's actions. It involves passive learning through association between a neutral stimulus and an unconditioned stimulus (e.g., Pavlov's dog salivating at the sound of a bell).

Learning is defined as a change in cognitive functioning (Option B): Incorrect. While learning can influence cognition, in behavioural theories, learning is specifically defined as a change in behaviour resulting from experience, not purely cognitive functioning.

Operant learning is a result of environmental events (Option C): Incorrect. Operant conditioning (Skinner) is about learning from the consequences of one's actions (rewards and punishments), not just passive environmental stimuli. Classical conditioning, on the other hand, is based on environmental stimulus pairing.

questions.text: A two-and-a-half-month-old boy discovers that he can make things happen. According to Piaget's cognitive development, which phenomenon of the sensorimotor stage has this boy developed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Circular reactions are repetitive actions that help infants learn cause and effect.
  • In primary circular reactions (1-4 months), babies repeat actions that are pleasurable or interesting, like sucking their thumb or kicking to move a hanging toy.
  • This boy's discovering he can make things happen (e.g., shaking a rattle makes noise) reflects the onset of intentional action, a hallmark of circular reactions.

Explanation of other options:

Egocentrism (Option B): Refers to difficulty in seeing perspectives other than one's own. This is a feature of the preoperational stage (2-7 years), not sensorimotor.

Object permanence (Option C): Understanding that objects continue to exist even when not visible. Develops later in the sensorimotor stage (around 8-12 months), not by 2.5 months.

Symbolic thought (Option D): Involves using symbols (like words or images) to represent objects or experiences. It emerges during the preoperational stage, not in infancy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is unable to see the world from his father's point of view, and his thinking is dominated by his perspective. Which stage of Piaget's cognitive development does this best describe?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The 5-year-old boy's inability to understand his father's point of view reflects egocentric thinking, which is a hallmark of Piaget's preoperational stage (ages 2-7 years).
  • In this stage, children are cognitively limited to seeing the world only from their perspective. They are not yet capable of mentally placing themselves in another person's position.
  • Piaget illustrated this concept using the Three Mountain Task, where children typically fail to describe what someone else sees from a different angle.
  • Thus, the boy's behaviour matches the characteristics of the preoperational stage.

questions.text: All of the following tools can be used to assess intelligence except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The 16-Personality Factor (16-PF) Test is not an intelligence test.
  • It is a personality assessment tool designed by Raymond Cattell to evaluate normal-range personality traits, such as warmth, reasoning, emotional stability, etc.
  • Therefore, it cannot be used to assess intelligence.
  • Scales for intelligence assessment are
    • Weschler Intelligence scale
    • Bhatia Battery test
    • Binet Kamat Scale

Explanation of other options:

Wechsler Intelligence Scale (Option B): This is a widely used intelligence test that measures different aspects of cognitive ability. Versions include WAIS (Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale) and WISC (Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children)

Bhatia Battery Test (Option C): An Indian test developed specifically to measure non-verbal intelligence, often used for children and people with language difficulties.

Bender Gestalt Test (Option D): Though primarily used to assess visual-motor integration and detect neurological impairments, it also provides indirect insights into developmental maturity, especially in children. It is not primarily an intelligence test, but it is still sometimes used in cognitive evaluations.

questions.text: All of the following tools can be used to assess personality except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Mini-Mental Status Examination (MMSE) is not a personality test.
  • It is a brief cognitive screening tool used primarily to assess orientation, attention, memory, language, and visuospatial skills, mainly in cases of dementia or cognitive impairment.
  • Hence, it does not assess personality.

Explanation of other options:

Rorschach Test (Option A): A projective personality test using inkblots. It assesses underlying thought disorder, perception, and personality structure.

TAT (Thematic Apperception Test) (Option B): Another projective test where a person is shown ambiguous pictures and asked to tell a story. It helps uncover unconscious motives, drives, and personality themes.

MMPI (Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory) (Option D): A structured, objective personality test used to diagnose psychiatric conditions and personality traits. It is one of the most scientifically validated personality tools.

questions.text: When deprived of food for more than 6 hours, a group of participants in an experiment would be more likely to interpret ambiguous pictures presented to them as something to do with food. This concept is the basis for:
questions.solution:
• The situation describes apperception, the process by which internal needs, emotions, and prior experiences shape how we interpret vague or ambiguous stimuli.
  • This is the foundation of projective personality tests, which assume people project unconscious aspects of their personality onto unclear images or scenarios.
  • These tests include:
    • Thematic Apperception Test (TAT): Subjects view ambiguous scenes and create stories, revealing their underlying thoughts, desires, and conflicts.
    • Children's Apperception Test (CAT): Like the TAT, but tailored for children, using animal characters to elicit stories based on the same projective principle.
    • Rorschach Inkblot Test: Subjects are shown inkblots and asked what they see. Their responses are believed to reflect unconscious thoughts and personality structure.

questions.text: A 64-year-old right-handed teacher retired from her position following 2 years of progressive difficulty recollecting the names of students and colleagues. However, apart from this naming deficit, no difficulty in performing routine tasks or any impairment in recollecting memories was found. Which type of memory is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • Semantic memory is a subcategory of declarative memory, which is responsible for general knowledge of the world, such as names, facts, and concepts (e.g., "Who is the president?", or "What is the capital of France?").
  • In this case, the teacher's progressive difficulty recollecting names suggests a problem with stored factual knowledge, i.e., semantic memory.

Explanation of other options:

Procedural memory (Option A): A type of nondeclarative memory, responsible for habits and motor skills (like riding a bike or typing). The patient had no issue performing tasks, so this is not affected.

Episodic memory (Option B): Another form of declarative memory, related to personal experiences and events. The patient has no difficulty recollecting personal events, only names.

Flashbulb memory (Option D): A type of episodic memory, involving vivid recall of emotionally charged events (e.g., remembering where you were during a traumatic event). This is not the type of memory being described in the scenario.

choices.text: Task A: Implicit memory, Task B: Explicit memory
Task A: Explicit memory, Task B: Implicit memory

questions.text:
Task A: You are asked to type 'There are three types of memory' without looking at the keyboard/ keypad
Task B: Recall the letters on the first line of the keyboard/ keypad.
For both tasks, what types of memory are involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Task A: Typing "There are three types of memory" without looking at the keyboard

  • This relies on procedural memory, a form of implicit memory, because the skill has been learned through repetition and is now performed automatically without conscious thought.
  • Implicit memory involves unconscious recall of motor skills or habits, like riding a bike or typing.

Task B: Recalling the letters on the first line of the keyboard

  • This requires conscious recall of factual information, which is handled by explicit (or declarative) memory.
  • Explicit memory includes semantic memory (knowledge of facts) and episodic memory (personal experiences).

questions.text: Deciding to take an antacid before indulging in a spicy meal to avoid gastric distress is an example of which form of learning?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Negative reinforcement occurs when a behaviour is strengthened because it removes or avoids an unpleasant stimulus.

  • In this case, the unpleasant stimulus is gastric distress.
  • Taking an antacid before eating spicy food is a preventive action, it helps avoid the negative experience.
  • Since this action reduces the likelihood of discomfort, it reinforces the behaviour of taking an antacid before spicy meals.

choices.text: It carries a risk of developing strong conditioned responses to the punisher
It carries the risk of developing negative feelings like depression, guilt, etc.
Mild punishment to suppress a behaviour, along with positive reinforcement to enforce another behaviour at the same time, may be most effective in the long run
It is the most effective form of learning to modulate a child's behaviour

questions.text: A child diagnosed with Attention-deficit-hyperactivity disorder is often beaten and scolded for his hyperactivity and impulsive episodes. Which of the following is false for this mode of learning to modulate behaviour?
questions.solution:
Explanation

Punishment refers to the use of punishers to suppress or stop a response from occurring in the future. This promotes the learning of what not to do.

The effectiveness of punishment depends on a few factors:

  • The more intense the punishment, the more effective it often is. Mild punishments tend to suppress behaviour only temporarily. However, intense punishment carries the risk that strong conditioned emotional responses will be developed with the punisher. Also, it may result in depression and guilt; hence, not considered the most effective form of learning to modulate a child's behaviour. (Option A & B ruled out)
  • The more consistently punishment is administered, the more effective it will be.
  • The closer the punishment is to the behaviour being punished in time and place, the more effective it will be.
  • Punishment, even when mild, can be quite effective if it is used to suppress one behaviour, while, at the same time, positive reinforcement is used to make another behaviour more likely to occur. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male, who once got trapped in an elevator, has now started avoiding all small enclosed spaces like other elevators, closed rooms, bathrooms, etc., for the fear that something embarrassing might happen to him there. The principle of Pavlovian conditioning, which explains this, is known as:
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • Stimulus generalisation occurs when a learned response to one stimulus is triggered by similar stimuli.
  • In this scenario, the man originally had a negative experience (getting trapped) in an elevator, and now he avoids other enclosed spaces like bathrooms or closed rooms, even though they weren't directly involved.
  • This fear response spreads from the original situation to other similar situations, which is the hallmark of stimulus generalisation in classical (Pavlovian) conditioning.

Explanation of Other Options:

Stimulus discrimination (Option A): This is the opposite of stimulus generalisation. It refers to the ability to distinguish between different stimuli and respond only to the specific conditioned stimulus, not to similar ones.

Extinction (Option C): Extinction refers to the gradual weakening and eventual disappearance of a conditioned response when the conditioned stimulus is repeatedly presented without the unconditioned stimulus. In this case, the fear is persisting or spreading, not fading, so extinction doesn't apply.

Aversion (Option D): Aversion refers to a learned dislike for a particular stimulus, often formed when that stimulus is paired with something unpleasant (like in taste aversion or aversion therapy). It usually refers to a specific stimulus, not a generalised group of them.

questions.text: A child diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder has been referred to a psychologist for assessment of Intelligence Quotient (IQ). What would be a more appropriate method of IQ assessment in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) often have:

  • Impairments in verbal communication, language development, and social reciprocity.
  • Better visual-spatial abilities and non-verbal problem-solving skills.

Performance IQ tasks are non-verbal and involve tasks like:

  • Puzzle solving
  • Pattern recognition
  • Picture arrangement

These are generally less affected by language deficits, making them more appropriate and reliable for assessing cognitive ability in children with autism.

Explanation of other options:

Verbal (Option A): Relies heavily on language comprehension and expression, which are typically impaired in ASD. Hence, it may underestimate the child's actual cognitive potential.

Analytical (Option C): Not a standard type of IQ category. "Analytical" is more commonly discussed in the context of Sternberg's Triarchic Theory (not standard IQ tests).

Practical (Option D): Also from Sternberg's Triarchic Theory (practical, analytical, and creative intelligence). Not used in formal IQ assessments like the WISC or Stanford-Binet scales.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy who presents with poor academic performance is assessed for his intelligence quotient by the Bhatia Battery test. His Mental age is around 10 years. Based on his level of IQ, what would be the percentage of disability according to the RPWD Act?
questions.solution:
Explanation


  • However, as per standard norms, the maximum chronological age used in this formula is 16 years.
  • According to this formula, the IQ of this patient would be 62 (Mental age 10 years/ Chronological age 16 years *100).
  • Since IQ 62 falls into the Mild Intellectual Disability category, it corresponds to approximately 50% disability.

questions.text: Parents of a 15-year-old boy observe that the academic performance of their child has deteriorated. On asking, the boy replies that he is no longer sure of his role in this world and this society. He is confused about what he wants to do in future and hence has developed less interest in academics. For him, all of the following statements are true except:
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • Erikson's 5th stage of psychosocial development is "Identity vs. Role Confusion" (ages 12-18 years).
  • At this stage, adolescents explore their identity, values, and goals.
  • Feeling uncertain about the future and struggling with one's role in society is normal during this stage.
  • Erikson emphasised that this identity crisis is a normative (not pathological) part of adolescent development.

Explanation of other options:

Fixation at this stage will hinder in development of the virtue of fidelity (Option B): True. Adolescents who resolve this crisis successfully develop fidelity, the ability to commit to others and their ideals. Failure leads to identity diffusion.

This is the fifth stage of psychosocial development given by Eric Erikson (Option C): True. "Identity vs. Role Confusion" is indeed Erikson's 5th stage out of 8.

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect because Option A is false, so not all statements are true.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl is brought by her parents with a history of frequent episodes of irritability, suicidal threats and excessive emotionality on trivial issues. On asking the patient, she denies having any symptoms and blames her parents for not raising her properly. She reports feeling chronically empty from inside. All of the following defence mechanisms explain her symptoms except:
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • Somatisation is the unconscious conversion of psychological distress into physical symptoms (e.g., pain, fatigue).
  • It is not a typical defence mechanism seen in Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD).
  • The clinical picture here is emotional dysregulation, interpersonal conflict, identity disturbance, and chronic feelings of emptiness, all pointing to BPD, not somatic symptom disorder.

Explanation for the Other Options:

Acting out (Option A): A primitive defence mechanism where emotional conflict is dealt with by actions rather than thoughts or feelings. Common in BPD, especially self-harm, suicidal threats, and impulsive outbursts, which are often responses to emotional dysregulation.

Denial (Option C): The refusal to accept external reality or facts. In BPD, denial can be seen when the patient refuses to acknowledge symptoms, blames others, or fails to see their part in emotional outbursts.

Projection (Option D): Attributing one's unacceptable thoughts or feelings to someone else. Seen here when the girl blames her parents for her problems, a classic feature in BPD, where internal distress is externalised.
